children.subject: It depends on the professor. I know sometimes you may get removed from the global list once an offer is made.

history.content:
Update: Yes, it is possible to get more than one offer, and many students do. If you accept an offer, you're strongly encouraged to keep it (although it is possible to back out, but this understandably creates difficulty for the faculty who have already hired you)

Edit: The department may not make second offers to those who have already been offered a position due to budget restrictions.

Update: Yes, it is possible to get more than one offer, and many students do. If you accept an offer, you're strongly encouraged to keep it (although it is possible to back out, but this understandably creates difficulty for the faculty who have already hired you)

The people who hire GSIs are not on piazza. I would encourage you to contact their email alias with this question. They should be able to tell you if the other Professors of interest have made their offers yet

children.subject: Just curious, what class is this for?

In most cases, you can be employed up to 50% (20 hours/week.) Most international students are ineligible to hold appointments over 50% during the academic year and should refer to the Berkeley International Office for specific visa restrictions. However, working at 50% is not always advisable depending on your workload. The department may not make second offers to those who have already been offered an appointment due to budget restrictions.

I'm a little confused because here it sounds like you cannot get an offer from two different classes, but in the Update section of the Instructor's answer it says "Yes, it is possible to get more than one offer, and many students do." If i got an offer, should I assume I will not get one from any other class?

+1

I find the wording "The department may not make second offers to those who have already been offered a position due to budget restrictions." ambiguous.  Does "may not" mean "is not allowed to" or "might or might not"?

In a meeting with the GSI hiring staff right now. They say that someone has to make a decision before being possibly offered any other positions. You are given three days, and you would have to accept or deny, before they may offer you another position. Otherwise, lots of students are holding pending positions for different classes and we struggle to actually finalize our hiring.

I wish this information was more publicly available. I haven't responded to one of my offers right now that I received three weeks ago, because it isn't my first choice, and I hadn't heard back from my other offers yet. I had emailed Diana Smith (the hiring coordinator) about this, but she did not mention anything of this nature (that I couldn't receive another offer).

In these sorts of situations, what is the suggested action to take?
@Steven, do you want to TA for 70 or 170 next semester?
Or was there another class you had in mind?
@Steven: Wait, didn't you graduate already last semester? ..

Well, I'm a currently a TA for CS188.

And no, I'm graduating in the fall.

Hi Steven, you should either accept or decline your offer if you want to receive another. There's no guarantee that you would receive another, though. If you have questions that are very specific to your situation, please do contact Diana directly.

I have been; my question was more rhetorical (hence why I didn't mark this follow-up as unresolved) as a comment about how poorly this system is implemented.

Logically, applicants will of course not accept or deny their offer before they hear back from their other choices (and the fact that professors don't tell applicants that they are rejected only stalls the hiring process even more).
Thanks for your feedback. We are working to make this process more transparent. This is good advice for the new website.
But can we actually accept two offers if we want to?

"In these sorts of situations, what is the suggested action to take?"

-- email the corresponding professor(s) and tell them that you are Steven Bi.

history.content:
(Note: I am not asking whether it is possible to TA more than one class at the same time.)

I applied to three different courses for a TA position.  If I have received a TA offer for one of them, does that mean I am no longer considered for the other classes?  I don't know how much (if any) discussion goes on amongst the faculty when they make hiring decisions.

The offer email says I must reply by July 8, but I'm not sure when the other courses' instructors will make their offers.
history.subject: Possible to receive more than one TA offer?
